26464284.owner: EDU GP AFR WEST & CENTRAL (GED07),Education - West/Central (AFTEW)
26464284.trustfund: TF021432-UN SPECIAL INITIATIVE FOR AFRICA,TF054879-NORWEGIAN EDUCATION TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Higher Education Project
            for Mauritania were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. The key lessons learned are as
            follows:  Policy reform is a complex undertaking and this
            awareness should be reflected in the project design. The
            visibility of Bank support should not be underestimated as
            it can act as an important catalyst in mobilizing resources
            from both the Government as well as other development
            partners. Bank teams should ensure the establishment of a
            robust M&E system in order to properly document the
            achievements and shortcomings of a Project. The Bank should
            ensure that procurement processes applied during
            implementation enable the Project to effectively evaluate
            the quality and adequacy of proposals and their associated
            bids. The cost of an intervention may not be directly
            proportional to its impact.

16385866.trustfund: TF021432-UN SPECIAL INITIATIVE FOR AFRICA,TF054879-NORWEGIAN EDUCATION TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
The Higher Education Project for
            Mauritania aims at: (i) improving the quality of the
            learning environment and the relevance of courses to the
            labor market; and (ii) establishing pedagogic,
            administrative and financial management systems in the
            Institutions of Higher Education (IHEs). The closing date
            for the project will be extended from March 31, 2012 until
            October 30, 2013. The original credit was in the amount of
            SDR 10.20 million (US$15 million equivalent), approved by
            the Board on August 3, 2004 and became effective on January
            12, 2005. The purpose of this extension request is to: (i)
            allow for the completion of contracts that have already been
            entered into but have not been completed; (ii) provide much
            needed higher education reform, civil works, goods and
            equipments; and (iii) complete ongoing activities necessary
            to achieve the Project Development Objective (PDO). Although
            actual disbursements only account for 35 percent of the
            credit, disbursements plus commitments amount to 63 percent
            and are mainly comprised of civil works activities. The
            remaining 37 percent will be used to procure pedagogical and
            Information Technology software and hardware to equip the
            buildings currently under construction.
